Watching John Cassavetes film, Opening Night, I was reminded of something that Quentin Tarantino said once in an interview about personal experience in being a creator. He said:
“I don’t think there’s any such thing as this big deep insight. You get them in life, sure. But the writer’s job is not to assemble them so much as to grow them larger and bring them up to some kind of clarity which is then shared with the writer. When you’re

A teen-aged girl gets the horse of her dreams and is trained by an ex-Jockey to participate in London's Grand National Steeplechase. In post- colonial London, she faces racism, sexism, and D-day celebrations – the intersection of class, racial, and other lines are limned in this quite readable novel.
I feel the horse and all the incidents are great. Other than that, not a great amount of depthness is developed for other characters.

Although there is melodrama at the center or rather at the bottom of this film, the story is told beautifully and subtly and the acting is superb.

Pierce Brosnan has sipped his last Martini and returns, in an outrageous self-parody, as the aging foul-mouthed boozy assassin Julian — a successor to Jack Ryan and Jason Bourne.

I loved October Sky. The thing I loved most had to be the music. It worked two ways: in the first hour of the film, it gives off a sense of yearning and excitement about unexplored futures. But then after listening to "suspended by music", I flipped my switch to hate.

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century.
